posts.title: Former police chief, serving murder and rape sentences, escapes from Arkansas prison.
top_comments:
Grant Hardin briefly served as the police chief in Gateway, a small town near the Missouri border, in 2016. He also held several other law enforcement positions in the state beginning in the 1990s. He was terminated multiple times, and trailed by reports of excessive force and poor performance. Hardin was a police officer in Eureka Springs, but resigned on October 4, 1996, after being told that he would be fired for falsifying a police report. He went on to serve as a constable for District 1 from 2009 to 2010 and 2013 to 2014. He later worked as correctional officer at the Northwest Arkansas Community Correction Center.

In February 2017, Hardin shot and killed 59-year-old James Appleton. According to an affidavit filed in the case, Appleton worked for the Gateway water department and was talking to his brother-in-law, then Gateway Mayor Andrew Tillman, when he was shot in the head near Garfield. His body was found inside a car. Hardin was charged with capital murder, but later pleaded guilty to a lesser charge of first degree murder and was sentenced to 30 years in prison. In court, he apologized, but never explained why he killed Appleton.

>"I wish I knew the motive. Grant Hardin is the only one that knows. He did not have the courage to tell it."

While in prison, Hardin was tied to an unsolved rape case from the 1990s. According to an affidavit filed in that case, Amy Harrison, an elementary schoolteacher and the wife of a police officer in Rogers, Arkansas, had arrived at her classroom on November 9, 1997, to prepare for the week. When she was leaving, she was confronted by a man who raped her at gunpoint. The attack occurred around the same time as a community church service down the hall. After Hardin went to prison, he was found to be a match for the DNA.

In 2018, Hardin pleaded guilty to rape and had 25 years added to his sentence.

posts.title: Japan flight made emergency landing after man tried opening door
top_comments: Just in case anyone is wondering, it's basically impossible to open the doors of a commercial airliner at altitude. They open inward first before swinging out, and the interior of the aircraft is pressurized when flying, forcing the door into its frame. That pressure applies too much interior force to the door for a human to overcome and prevents it from opening.

When my sister flew with Air New Zealand as a stewardess, she relates how a gentleman came up to her in the galley, and asked if he could get off. He said he’d had enough of flying and just wanted off. He was subsequently gently sedated.

A Japanese plane headed from Tokyo to Texas had to make an emergency landing after a passenger tried to open one of its doors during the flight.

All Nippon Airways (ANA) Flight 114 was diverted to Seattle hours after taking off on Saturday "due to an unruly passenger", the airline said.

Port of Seattle police told media they had been notified of a man who "attempted to open exit doors during the flight".

I keep seeing headlines about people doing this. Whats actually happening with these people? What “medical crisis” makes someone think they can just open a door and get off an airplane in mid-air? Are they on weird sleep/anxiety medications and having some sort of reaction or episode? Are they crazy and having a delusion?
A lot of very not-normal people going to Japan for trips recently. It makes me not want to go just to not contribute to their disrespectful tourist epidemic, even if I'd never be of that group.

It’s coming to the point where I am constantly seeing people not knowing how to behave or being dangerous on flights that I wouldn’t be surprised if you had to have a background check and interview to be allowed on planes in the future

posts.title: Former police chief, serving murder and rape sentences, escapes from Arkansas prison.
top_comments:
Grant Hardin briefly served as the police chief in Gateway, a small town near the Missouri border, in 2016. He also held several other law enforcement positions in the state beginning in the 1990s. He was terminated multiple times, and trailed by reports of excessive force and poor performance. Hardin was a police officer in Eureka Springs, but resigned on October 4, 1996, after being told that he would be fired for falsifying a police report. He went on to serve as a constable for District 1 from 2009 to 2010 and 2013 to 2014. He later worked as correctional officer at the Northwest Arkansas Community Correction Center.

In February 2017, Hardin shot and killed 59-year-old James Appleton. According to an affidavit filed in the case, Appleton worked for the Gateway water department and was talking to his brother-in-law, then Gateway Mayor Andrew Tillman, when he was shot in the head near Garfield. His body was found inside a car. Hardin was charged with capital murder, but later pleaded guilty to a lesser charge of first degree murder and was sentenced to 30 years in prison. In court, he apologized, but never explained why he killed Appleton.

>"I wish I knew the motive. Grant Hardin is the only one that knows. He did not have the courage to tell it."

While in prison, Hardin was tied to an unsolved rape case from the 1990s. According to an affidavit filed in that case, Amy Harrison, an elementary schoolteacher and the wife of a police officer in Rogers, Arkansas, had arrived at her classroom on November 9, 1997, to prepare for the week. When she was leaving, she was confronted by a man who raped her at gunpoint. The attack occurred around the same time as a community church service down the hall. After Hardin went to prison, he was found to be a match for the DNA.

In 2018, Hardin pleaded guilty to rape and had 25 years added to his sentence.

posts.title: Japan flight made emergency landing after man tried opening door
top_comments: Just in case anyone is wondering, it's basically impossible to open the doors of a commercial airliner at altitude. They open inward first before swinging out, and the interior of the aircraft is pressurized when flying, forcing the door into its frame. That pressure applies too much interior force to the door for a human to overcome and prevents it from opening.

When my sister flew with Air New Zealand as a stewardess, she relates how a gentleman came up to her in the galley, and asked if he could get off. He said he’d had enough of flying and just wanted off. He was subsequently gently sedated.

A Japanese plane headed from Tokyo to Texas had to make an emergency landing after a passenger tried to open one of its doors during the flight.

All Nippon Airways (ANA) Flight 114 was diverted to Seattle hours after taking off on Saturday "due to an unruly passenger", the airline said.

Port of Seattle police told media they had been notified of a man who "attempted to open exit doors during the flight".
